image.altText: A Palestinian stands next to a destroyed building.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says Israel will press ahead with its plans to wipe out Hamas as Israeli troops and tanks attack Gaza's main northern city from the east and west.

title.children: Netanyahu rejects calls for ceasefire as Israeli tanks attack Gaza's main city

image.altText: A group of soldiers in a vehicle

items.synopsis: For weeks, the objectives of Israel's ground assault in Gaza have remained obscured by a veil of secrecy. But as tanks push further and further into the coastal enclave, a plan is starting to take shape.

title.children: Israel's war plan in Gaza is shrouded in secrecy, but clues are starting to emerge. Here's what we know

image.altText: CCTV image shows three people on the floor and a person on a phone.

items.synopsis: The family of an Aboriginal man who died after an incident involving two security guards says new allegations of violence in the industry show lessons have not been learnt.

title.children: This man yelled 'I can't breathe' before he died. There was no global outcry

image.altText: Renewable energy: wind and solar.

items.synopsis: Satellite data shows the massive explosion of rooftop solar from above, but the rest of Australia's energy transition is falling behind. Search for your suburb's rooftop solar count.

title.children: Why rooftop solar is so crucial for Australia's renewable targets

image.altText: A person wearing a bike helmet standing at an empty bank counter

items.synopsis: Kym Parsons's lawyer says his client had lost 7 kilograms in custody, and argues that denying bail would condemn him to death without a trial.

title.children: Terminally ill alleged 'bicycle bandit' to be released on bail

image.altText: A sign saying "Australian Government Department of Home Affairs" outside a tall building. There are leaves in the foreground

items.synopsis: Australia's 888 visa system that has granted 26,000 "golden visas' to the super rich is out of step with the rest of the world, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: The super rich have a golden ticket to Australia — but what is it costing?

image.altText: A bald middle aged white man. He's sitting in a wheelchair and wearing a blue sweater

items.synopsis: A Victorian man is taking his fight to become an NDIS participant to the UN, accusing the Australian government of age discrimination and breaching his human rights.

title.children: NDIS access would change Peter's life, but he's locked out and says the reason is 'cruel and unfair'

image.altText: A wide sweeping river with an orange sunset

items.synopsis: The federal government reveals irrigators have registered nearly twice the volume of water it intends to purchase this year, while an interim report from the Productivity Commission calls for sweeping changes to get the basin plan completed on time.

title.children: Irrigators register 'more than twice' the volume of water sought under federal government water buyback program

image.altText: Chinese President Xi Jinping talks to Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands in a 2019 meeting.

items.synopsis: A leading think tank is warning the Australian government to be careful not to overload Pacific countries with debt in China's absence.

title.children: Researchers say the Pacific has 'woken up' to Chinese investment: Where does that leave Australia?

image.altText: A pictorial representation of Australian GDP sitting on the edge of a cliff.

items.synopsis: Like Looney Tunes' famous cartoon villain, the Reserve Bank risks running Australia's economy over a cliff if it becomes too single-minded in its pursuit of the inflation Road Runner, writes Michael Janda.

title.children: Is Australia's economy facing a Wile E Coyote cliff-top moment as the RBA ponders further rate hikes?

image.altText: Maddy Zarb sitting in a wheelchair looking at the camera

items.synopsis: What was supposed to be a joyous trip to watch her beloved Blues in an AFL final turned to heartbreak for a teacher who is facing mounting costs.

title.children: When Maddy's wheelchair was broken on a flight she felt stranded. What happened next left her disgusted

image.altText: A film still showing an older man wearing a cowboy hat sitting in a vehicle talking to a younger man in a hat and striped coat

items.synopsis: Studios have cracked down on a handful of overseas cinemas for running Killers of the Flower Moon with an interval, but the head of two dozen cinemas in Australia says customers should be given a choice.

title.children: 'It's about choice': Cinema CEO blasts studios over no interval for Killers of the Flower Moon

image.altText: Hamas militants with their faces covered with masks on the back of a truck holding weapons.

items.synopsis: Despite having a highly advanced military, on the ground in Gaza Israeli soldiers will be facing off with Hamas in scenarios that could make some of their weapons obsolete and work in the militants' favour.

title.children: Battles in Gaza will be 'very, very messy'. These are the weapons both sides are working with

image.altText: A human hand holds up a cane toad from the back legs to torch light at a dark Kimberley waterbody

items.synopsis: Scientists have dropped sausages made out of cane toads to deter vulnerable wildlife in the Kimberley from eating the pest. Unfortunately, the snags don't appear to be working, but there's another plan afoot to protect the Pilbara.

title.children: Air-dropped cane toad snags may not be the solution to extinctions Australia was hoping for

image.altText: A man wearing a blue and white button up shirt leans his elbow on a fence and looks out over the beach

items.synopsis: Seok Hee Lee grew up in Australia after immigrating from South Korea nearly two decades ago. When his mum applied for a visa, he was considered a dependent child. But after years of waiting for the application to be processed, Mr Lee's application was denied — because he is now an adult.

title.children: Lengthy parent visa processing times pose challenges for children

image.altText: A helicopter flies over a ship on open water.

items.synopsis: The Israel-Gaza war and Russia's invasion of Ukraine could become "strategic distractions" for the United States, a senior US military figure warns, saying a dangerous world creates circumstances that can strain resources.

title.children: Middle East and Ukraine conflicts risk causing 'strategic distraction' for US in Indo-Pacific

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair sits facing away from the camera, looking out at a green field.

items.synopsis: New data shows nearly one-third of Australians aged 18 or 19 have experienced intimate partner violence in the past year. Those involved in the support sector say they are shocked by the level of violence some young people are experiencing.

title.children: Sarah was only 16 when a boyfriend assaulted her. She didn't know where a teenager could turn to for help

image.altText: Three burnt out cars sit in the dirt.

items.synopsis: Queensland firefighters continue to work tirelessly to contain a major blaze at Tara, with conditions expected to flare up again on Tuesday.

title.children: Firefighters warn of 'significant deterioration' in weather conditions as 70 fires burn across Queensland

image.altText: A small shark with black spots lays on the sea floor.

items.synopsis: A world-first shark 'rewilding' project is helping the endangered zebra shark, but it could also provide a template to help save other threatened marine species.

title.children: Sharks on a plane: An ambitious international project is helping save this endangered species

image.altText: A woman pours a beer from the tap at a bar.

items.synopsis: If you've been to a pub, restaurant, cafe or fast food outlet recently, you've most likely experienced increased wait times accompanied by the apology: "Sorry, we're short staffed".

title.children: 'Tired, grumpy, cranky': Hospitality sector desperate for workers plugs roster gaps with existing staff, family members

image.altText: A Qantas jumbo takes off

items.synopsis: Qantas has launched its legal defence in the ACCC "ghost flights" case — allegedly selling 8,000 flights that were already cancelled — arguing what it did was reasonable and that "airlines can't guarantee specific flight times".

title.children: 'Qantas can't guarantee flights', airline says as it launches defence in ACCC 'ghost flights' case

image.altText: a woman in a hospital bed holding hands with another person

items.synopsis: The ACT government introduces its voluntary assisted dying bill to the Legislative Assembly, after a decades-long fight to legislate on the issue.

title.children: As the ACT begins to legislate for voluntary assisted dying, here's how the laws could differ from elsewhere

image.altText: An elderly man in a blue suit, white shirt, red tie, looks on with a neutral expression

items.synopsis: The federal judge overseeing Donald Trump's 2020 election interference case in Washington has reimposed a narrow gag order barring him from making public comments targeting prosecutors, court staff and potential witnesses.

title.children: Federal judge reimposes gag order on Donald Trump in 2020 election interference case

image.altText: A file phot of the cast of the hit television series Friends sitting on a red couch.

items.synopsis: Family, fellow actors and Friends creators have spoken publicly of their heartbreak over the 54-year-old's passing.

title.children: 'The world will miss you': Touching tributes to Matthew Perry following actor's death

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: Rubiales resigned in September from his position as RFEF president, saying his position had become untenable.

title.children: FIFA bans former Spanish football president Luis Rubiales for three years after World Cup kiss

image.altText: Lilie James, who was killed at St Andrew's Cathedral School in Sydney's CBD on October 25, 2023, smiling in an undated selfie

items.synopsis: The grandmother of 21-year-old Lilie James says she was a "beautiful young woman" as she recalled memories of Lilie as a child. On Monday, staff and students return for a memorial service to the school where she was killed.

title.children: Lilie James's family 'cannot understand' why she was killed at Sydney school

image.altText: Seyyed Abdolzadeh Ali Farshchi dressed in shirt and tie  with a cup of tea and cake

items.synopsis: Doctor Seyyed Farshchi is found guilty of forced labour offences, including not paying a refugee for three months.

title.children: Melbourne doctor found guilty, wife cleared over sweet shop slavery

image.altText: A bottle of sparkling wine is about to be poured

items.synopsis: A massive trade deal with the European Union appears all but doomed after "endgame" negotiations between the two sides collapsed before they even began.

title.children: Australian producers to keep prosecco, feta and parmesan as EU trade deal doomed

image.altText: Associate Professor Astghik Mavisakalyan

items.synopsis: In early 2024, more than 4.6 million workers are about to find out how much less the company they work for pays female staff. Many companies are working now to fix the problem.

title.children: How to fix the gender pay gap, according to one of the 'bloke-iest' companies in Australia

image.altText: A composite image showing the faces of Australia's last six prime ministers.

items.synopsis: Australia's living prime ministers, except for Paul Keating, make a rare joint statement in solidarity with Jewish Australians, and urging Israel to use "humanity and skill" in its operation against Hamas in Gaza.

title.children: Former prime ministers join to condemn Hamas, urge Israel to protect civilian lives

image.altText: Bruce Fairfax, photographed with his dog.

items.synopsis: The Tasmanian man was reported missing on a bushwalk with his wife and their dog six years ago but now police say they're reinterviewing old witnesses.

title.children: Bruce Fairfax and his wife went for a bushwalk six years ago. What happened is now part of a criminal probe

image.altText: A pan full of rice with hands stirring with a wooden spoon and adding soy sauce.

items.synopsis: A condition dubbed "fried rice syndrome" refers to food poisoning from a bacterium called Bacillus cereus, which becomes a risk when cooked food is left at room temperature for too long. Here's what to know and how to protect yourself, writes Enzo Palombo

title.children: Has 'fried rice syndrome' caused your food poisoning? Here's how the two-hour/four-hour rule can help

image.altText: Analyn 'Logee' Osias smiles for a selfie with the sun softly shining on tents behind her.

items.synopsis: A community is in mourning and a 44-year-old man is assisting police with their enquiries after the death of Analyn "Logee" Osias in the Bendigo suburb of Kangaroo Flat.

title.children: Bendigo woman Analyn 'Logee' Osias mourned after death

image.altText: A red kelpie leans over the back of a ute tray and licks its nose.

items.synopsis: A GPS tracker on Earl's collar has shown he can run faster and longer than all the other top working dogs in Australia. His owner Alex says he'd be lost without the loyal, hardworking kelpie by his side.

title.children: What makes Earl, a half-blind kelpie, the best working dog in Australia?
